speaker: Elena
text: This article makes a rather audacious claim right out of the gate: the military isn't for defending borders anymore.

speaker: James
text: [dry] Audacious, but hard to argue with, isn't it? Afghanistan, Iraq, Libya – none were exactly poised to invade Kent.

speaker: Elena
text: Exactly. The idea it's about humanitarian intervention also falls apart when you compare Libya to Syria, for instance.

speaker: James
text: Indeed. Selective morality, it seems. But the numbers around energy security? They're truly staggering.

speaker: Elena
text: Mind-boggling, James. The article claims the US essentially subsidises Persian Gulf oil at $795 per barrel.

speaker: James
text: [surprised] Wait, really? Seven hundred and ninety-five dollars? That's... actually devastating.

speaker: Elena
text: Compared to pumping it out at $2 a barrel. It makes zero economic sense for the US taxpayer.

speaker: James
text: No, it doesn't. Even for a fiscally conservative hawk, those numbers are utterly indefensible.

speaker: Elena
text: It directly links to our other piece on the 'renewables and battery revolution'. Why are we paying for this fossil fuel folly?

speaker: James
text: Eisenhower warned us about the military-industrial complex back in '61. He saw this kind of misdirection coming.

speaker: Elena
text: But the scale of it is just obscene. $7.3 trillion between 1976 and 2007 for the Persian Gulf fleet alone.

speaker: James
text: A staggering sum. And for what? To make the Muslim world perceive the West as aggressive, driving up the cost further.

speaker: Elena
text: It's a self-fulfilling prophecy of conflict, funded by the very people it supposedly protects.

speaker: James
text: Absolutely. If you're paying nearly $800 a barrel for oil that costs $2 to extract, you're doing it wrong.

speaker: Elena
text: And it's not just oil. The Pacific Command budget is equally baffling: $137 billion per year in 2011.

speaker: James
text: To protect sea-lanes. A fifth of the entire US military budget, focused on one region.

speaker: Elena
text: But the article points out the brutal irony: that spending protects routes that facilitate trade deficits of $400 billion annually.

speaker: James
text: [thoughtful] Hmm. A very aggressive way to 'hollow out' your own economy, as the piece puts it.

speaker: Elena
text: It's like paying someone to take your job. It actively undermines the very idea of national economic interest.

speaker: James
text: I hadn't considered the trade deficit as a direct *cost* of the military itself. That's a powerful point, Elena.

speaker: Elena
text: It's not just a deficit, it's a transfer of jobs, skills, and capital. We discussed this in 'Crisis: Or An Explanation On The Origins Of The Decline Of The West'.

speaker: James
text: No, you're right. The correlation is clear. But what's the alternative? A truly minimal military, relying on militias? The Founding Fathers' ideal seems a bit anachronistic now.

speaker: Elena
text: The article isn't calling for no military, just a re-evaluation of its purpose. Defending borders, yes. Projecting power overseas for these specific reasons? No.

speaker: James
text: Fair enough. But China's rise, for instance – 'an emerging colonial power' as we discussed in another piece. You don't deter that with just a coastguard.

speaker: Elena
text: Deterrence is one thing. Subsidising your own economic decline is another entirely. That $137 billion could be better spent on domestic innovation, couldn't it?

speaker: James
text: [conceding] Okay, fine. I'll give you that. The data on trade deficits directly linked to military protection is stark. It's a bizarre subsidy.

speaker: Elena
text: It's not just bizarre, it's destructive. Imagine if that capital went into green energy or education instead.

speaker: James
text: The article's idea of setting up tariff barriers for manufacturing, to keep jobs within trading zones... it's not my usual stance.

speaker: Elena
text: But if the alternative is paying $137 billion to accelerate the 'hollowing out' of your own economy, is protectionism really that radical a solution?

speaker: James
text: [thinking aloud] If the military spending *itself* is enabling a system that actively harms your economic base... then it flips the whole strategic argument on its head.

speaker: Elena
text: It absolutely does. It's a self-defeating strategy, plain and simple.

speaker: James
text: I don't *want* to agree with you on a return to tariffs, but the numbers on the Pacific Command budget plus the trade deficit... that's a powerful, uncomfortable combination.

speaker: Elena
text: The article ends with a note of optimism: 'The West's romance with Free Trade is ending.' This military analysis certainly backs that up.

speaker: James
text: An expensive romance, indeed. And one that's left us rather vulnerable, I think.

speaker: Elena
text: It presents a clear path to a healthier global economy, and less need for these costly, counterproductive military interventions.

speaker: James
text: If. That's a very big 'if'. The military-industrial complex is a formidable beast.

speaker: Elena
text: But the evidence is there. We just have to look at it, unflinchingly, and decide if we want to keep paying the price.
